q: What is a determinant?
a: A determinant is a scalar value calculated from a square matrix. It represents the volume scaling factor of the linear transformation described by the matrix and helps in solving systems of equations.

q: How is the determinant of a 2x2 matrix calculated?
a: For \( A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \), the determinant is given by: \( |A| = ad - bc \)

q: How is the determinant of a 3x3 matrix calculated?
What is the geometric interpretation of a determinant?
a: The absolute value of the determinant of a matrix represents the area (2D) or volume (3D) of the figure formed by the column vectors of the matrix.

q: What is the effect on determinant when two rows (or columns) are interchanged?
a: Interchanging two rows or columns of a determinant changes its sign. That is, \( |A'| = -|A| \).

q: What happens to the determinant if two rows (or columns) are identical?
a: If any two rows or columns are identical, then the determinant is zero.

q: What is the effect on the determinant when a row (or column) is multiplied by a scalar \(k\)?
a: The determinant gets multiplied by \(k\). That is, \( |A'| = k|A| \)

q: What is the value of determinant if the matrix has a row or column of zeros?
a: If any row or column of a matrix is entirely zero, the determinant is zero.

q: What is the determinant of an identity matrix?
a: The determinant of an identity matrix is always 1, i.e., \( |I_n| = 1 \).

q: State the property: \( |A^T| = ? \)
a: \( |A^T| = |A| \). That is, the determinant of the transpose of a matrix is equal to the determinant of the matrix itself.

q: If \( |A| \neq 0 \), what can be said about the matrix \(A\)?
a: If \( |A| \neq 0 \), then the matrix \(A\) is invertible (non-singular).

q: If \( |A| = 0 \), what can be said about the matrix \(A\)?
a: If \( |A| = 0 \), then the matrix \(A\) is singular and not invertible.

q: What is the adjoint of a matrix?
a: The adjoint (or adjugate) of a square matrix is the transpose of the cofactor matrix.\ For \(A\), \( \text{adj}(A) = (\text{cof}(A))^T \)

q: What is the inverse of a matrix using adjoint?
a: If \(A\) is a non-singular matrix, then:\ \[ A^{-1} = \frac{\text{adj}(A)}{|A|} \]

q: How do you solve a system of equations using Cramer's Rule?
a:
For a system \( AX = B \), if \( |A| \neq 0 \):\ 
\[ x = \frac{|A_1|}{|A|}, \quad y = \frac{|A_2|}{|A|}, \quad z = \frac{|A_3|}{|A|} \]\ where \(A_i\) is the matrix obtained by replacing the \(i^{th}\) column of \(A\) by the column matrix \(B\).

q: What is a cofactor?
a: The cofactor of an element \(a_{ij}\) is \(C_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}M_{ij}\), where \(M_{ij}\) is the minor of \(a_{ij}\).

q: What is a minor?
a: The minor of an element \(a_{ij}\) is the determinant of the submatrix formed by deleting the \(i^{th}\) row and \(j^{th}\) column.

q: What is the expansion of a determinant along a row?
a:
To expand along the \(i^{th}\) row:\ 
\[ |A| = a_{i1}C_{i1} + a_{i2}C_{i2} + \dots + a_{in}C_{in} \]

q: What is the expansion of a determinant along a column?
a:
To expand along the \(j^{th}\) column:\ 
\[ |A| = a_{1j}C_{1j} + a_{2j}C_{2j} + \dots + a_{nj}C_{nj} \]

q: What is the value of \( |kA| \), where \(k\) is a scalar and \(A\) is an \(n \times n\) matrix?
What is the determinant of a product of two matrices?
a: \( |AB| = |A| \cdot |B| \)

q: If \( |A| = 5 \), what is \( |3A| \) for a 3Ã—3 matrix?

a: \( |AB| = |A| \cdot |B| = 7 \times 2 = 14 \)

q: State the identity: \( \text{adj}(A) \cdot A = ? \)
a: \( \text{adj}(A) \cdot A = |A| \cdot I \), where \(A\) is a square matrix.

q: What is \( A \cdot \text{adj}(A) \)?
a: Same as \( \text{adj}(A) \cdot A = |A| \cdot I \). Matrix multiplication with adjoint works both sides.

q: What is \( \text{adj}(A^T) \)?
a: \( \text{adj}(A^T) = (\text{adj}(A))^T \)

q: What is \( \text{adj}(kA) \)?
a: If \(A\) is an \(n \times n\) matrix and \(k\) is a scalar, then:\ \( \text{adj}(kA) = k^{n-1} \cdot \text{adj}(A) \)

q: What is \( |\text{adj}(A)| \) for an \(n \times n\) matrix?
If \( |A| = 0 \), what is \( \text{adj}(A) \)?
a: If \( |A| = 0 \), then \( \text{adj}(A) \cdot A = 0 \Rightarrow \text{adj}(A) \) is **not necessarily zero**, but \( A^{-1} \) does not exist.
